properties.title: Alice Austin Park Staten Island Before and After Sandy
properties.description: Tomathon posted a photo: Two views of Alice Austen Park in Rosebank, Staten Island. Each compare similar photos taken October 5th and October 31st, 2012

properties.title: Hurricane Sandy 01c - Brigantine - Absecon Inlet
properties.description: Brian's Lens posted a photo: View over the decks of the two very large houses on Sunset Circle looking out over Absecon Inlet towards Atlantic City during Hurricane Sandy. Their two decks meet in a point at the corner 25 feet from the jetty (breakwater). The white deck (left) is parallel to the ocean, the pink deck (right) is parallel to the inlet. Look at the map to get a sense of how exposed this area is. The wind and waves are usually coming towards the photographer (from that point in Atlantic City, across the inlet, to Brigantine) and that is what you are seeing here.

properties.title: Hurricane Sandy 08b - Brigantine - Brigantine Avenue Flooding
properties.description: Brian's Lens posted a photo: Shot of flooding on Brigantine Blvd. as you enter the island off of the bridge, probably taken Tuesday morning, Oct. 30th. If you look at the map, you will see why there is flooding. Brigantine Avenue is just a narrow strip of land between the bay and St. Georges Thorofare.

properties.title: Alice Austin Park Staten Island Before and After Sandy
properties.description: Tomathon posted a photo: Two views of Alice Austen Park in Rosebank, Staten Island. Each compare similar photos taken October 5th and October 31st, 2012

properties.title: Hurricane Sandy 01d - Brigantine - Absecon Inlet Damage
properties.description: Brian's Lens posted a photo: This is a view toward the ocean along Absecon Inlet, looking towards the two houses at the point from which Photo 01c was taken. Photos 01a and 01b are looking towards this spot. As you can see, the jetty (breakwater) is only 25-50 feet from these houses. The pic pretty much confrims my beleif that most damage would be flooding related. Note that there are no missing roofs, siding or hangin flashing, even though this area is very exposed (sand routinely builds up in the street behind these houses during the winter). The piece of deck lying in the foreground is from the third house down. If you have been here, the new large off white/gray stucco/stone house with the "turret" and the plastic grass is right behind the photographer. Tweeted at 11:30 am Tuesday. Source @delay_knee

properties.title: Hurricane Sandy 08a - Brigantine - Bridge & Flooding
properties.description: Brian's Lens posted a photo: Shot from Golden Nugget looking across Absecon Inlet towards Brigantine showing flooding on Brigantine Blvd. This was tweeted around 1 pm on Tuesday, Oct. 30th. If you look at the map you can see why there is flooding. If the timing on the tweet is when the pic was taken, then it was taken at high tide (and high tide was about 6 feet yesterday).

properties.title: Hurricane Sandy 04d - Brigantine - North End Damage
properties.description: Brian's Lens posted a photo: Looking south from approximately the same place I took Photo 04a, after the storm atthe very north end of the island along the seawall. I believe that building is NOT a house, but rather a lifeguard shack that was not secured properly before the storm. 11 am Tuesday. Tweeted by twitter.com/thetonysicilia

properties.title: Hurricane Sandy 06b - Brigantine - North End Flooding
properties.description: Brian's Lens posted a photo: Looking west from the seawall in the north end. This picture was taken from about where the tall building with the red roof is in Photo 04d, looking to the right. You can see the sand that the waves pushed over the seawall. 11 am Tuesday. Tweeted by twitter.com/thetonysicilia

properties.title: Ambulance Convoy I
properties.description: edenpictures posted a photo: A line of maybe 20 ambulances driving down Second Avenue without sirens--a spooky thing to see in one's neighborhood.

properties.title: After the Flood
properties.description: edenpictures posted a photo: This is I believe Sixth Street, which had water up to the car windows at the height of the flood.

properties.title: Tompkins Post-Sandy
properties.description: edenpictures posted a photo: There were quite a few downed limbs, not too many fallen trees, at least that were visible from the periphery. (The park was still closed as of October 31.)
